text: Mr. Spicer: Good afternoon, everybody.
Thanks for coming.
Last night, the President was honored to announce
Judge Neil Gorsuch as his nominee to serve as the
next Justice of the Supreme Court.
It was an unbelievably phenomenal evening.
Immediately after being announced, Judge Gorsuch
was honored to meet with Maureen and Father Scalia.
As some of you have reported, his first call
after coming back behind the podium was to Merritt
Garland who had also note, has already come out to
say Judge Gorsuch deserves a fair hearing.
In less than 24 hours, Judge Gorsuch has already
received a wide-spread praise from across the
political spectrum as an inspired choice with
sterling academic credentials; a brilliant
legal mind; and, a steadfast commitment to
constitutional principles.
During his long career in public service, Judge
Gorsuch has enjoyed bipartisan approval,
having previously been confirmed by voice
vote to the U.S.
Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit.
In fact, 12 current Democratic senators,
including Minority Leader, Chuck Schumer, Senator
Dianne Feinstein, Senator Leahy were all in office
when he was first confirmed without
opposition in 2006.
With as many as eight Democrats like, Senator
Blumenthal, Durbin, McCaskill, already
supporting a full hearing and vote for Judge
Gorsuch, there is no question that he is a
widely respected jurist who deserves to have his
nomination fairly decided upon by the
United States Senate.
Now that Judge Gorsuch has been officially named, I
hope you all will allow me to talk for a moment about
how exceptionally qualified he is to succeed
the late, great, Antonin Scalia.
Judge Gorsuch&#39;s academic record is impeccable and
as he said last night, the President holds education
in the highest regard.
Judge Gorsuch graduated kappa-be -- phi kappa beta
from Columbia; graduated cum laude from Harvard Law
School and attended Oxford as a recipient of the
prestigious Marshall Scholarship.
Like Justice Scalia, the cornerstone of Judge
Gorsuch&#39;s judicial philosophy is fidelity
to the text.
He believes that judges should not base their
decisions solely on the law -- he believes --
sorry, I don&#39;t want to screw that one up -- that
his decisions should be based solely on the law
and the Constitution, not on their own policies,
preferences or personal feelings.
He will be a reliable and principled voice on the
bench, preserving equal justice under the law
regardless of background.
And I would note, I think -- I always want to caveat
this, but to my understanding, I think he
would be the first justice that will serve with a --
with the -- as someone he clerked for on the bench.
So, it will be a sort -- a first when he is confirmed
by the Senate.
Now, on to the issues of the day -- today is
February 1st, which means we are kicking off Black
History Month.
The President has events planned throughout the
month starting today with a listening session that
occurred early this morning with African
American leaders in the Roosevelt Room.
The meeting also included some of the
Administration&#39;s African American appointees.
Later today, the President
will issue a proclamation. The U.S.
Postal Service kicked off the month by issuing the
Dorothy Height Forever Stamp, the 40th stamp in
their black heritage series.
Dr. Height led the National Council of Negro
Women for four decades and was awarded the
Presidential Medal of Freedom by President Bill
Clinton in 1994 and the Congressional Medal of
Freedom by President George W.
Bush in 2004 -- excuse me, 1994 and 2004.
President Obama delivered her eulogy in 2010, and
President Trump is now proud that the Post Office
is honoring her incredible legacy as a
Civil Rights icon.
At events throughout this entire month, we&#39;ll
celebrate the contributions of
courageous African American leaders from
Harriet Tubman and Frederick Douglass to
Martin Luther King, Jr. and Clarence Thomas.
African American History is American History, and
this month is a great reminder of that.
Continuing with today&#39;s schedule, the Vice
President went to the Hill with Judge Gorsuch to meet
with lawmakers from the first time since being
named last night.
On the Hill, the Vice President will -- met with
Majority Leader McConnell and the staff spearheading
Judge Gorsuch&#39;s nomination will also meet with
Senators Cornyn, Grassley, Hatch and Gardener.
With Judge Gorsuch on Capitol Hill, I think it&#39;s
a good time to talk about the confirmation process.
Neither of the two Supreme Court Justices that
President Obama nominated were subject to the
60-vote threshold of the Senate filibuster.
They received bipartisan support because
Republicans, despite some political and
philosophical differences, viewed them as
mainstream and qualified.
And Judge Gorsuch shall
receive the same fair treatment.
Also, this morning, the President met in the
Roosevelt Room with representatives of outside
groups to discuss Judge Gorsuch&#39;s nomination,
including David O&#39;Steen of the National Right to
Life; Paula White of the New Destiny Christian
Center; Wayne LaPierre of the National Rifle
Association; Penny Nance of Concerned Women of
America; Charmaine Yoest of American Values;
Juanita Duggan of the National Federation of
Independent Businesses; Tom Collimore of the
United States Chamber of Commerce; Grover Norquist
of Americans for Tax Reform; Leonard Leo of the
Federalists Society; Marjorie Dannenfelser of
the Susan B.
Anthony List; and, Morton Blackwell of the
Leadership Institute.
President Trump told the group that his decision on
the Supreme Court is among the most important
decisions he will ever make as president.
He praised Judge Gorsuch for his academic and
professional achievements and his lifelong
devotion to the law.
The attendees thanked the President for making such
an inspired choice and for delivering what was, for
many of them, their number issue in the campaign.
They committed vocally to supporting Judge Gorsuch
throughout the confirmation process and
expressed their desire for the Senate to move swiftly
to give him a fair hearing and vote.
The meeting closed with the President inviting the
group into the Oval Office, which several
attendees really enjoyed that honor.
The President then had lunch with Secretary of
State Designee Tillerson.
Mr. Tillerson&#39;s tenacity, broad experience, and deep
understanding of the geo-politics are going to
make him an outstanding chief diplomat for
the United States.
And the President is looking forward to the
full vote of the Senate on his nomination.
Later this evening, the President will participate
in a standing legislative affairs strategy meeting
with his team who have been working closely with
Congress to enact the President&#39;s agenda.
So far, between the Vice President and staff, we&#39;ve
had as many productive conversations with members
of both parties on both chambers on a variety of
issues from trade to the President&#39;s nomination for
his cabinet, and now the Supreme Court.
Now, starting this week, our legislative affairs
team will also conduct excessive outreach on
behalf of Judge Gorsuch&#39;s nomination process.
Clearly, this Administration has made
reaching out to Congress a top priority, but you know
where I&#39;m going with that.
Democrats in the Senate continue to use every tool
at their disposal to try to get a way of the
President&#39;s attempts to make the country -- to
make America great again.
Just today, Senate Democrats again, refused
to even participate in committee votes for Senate
designates price and (inaudible) who were moved
out of the Finance Committee with zero
Democrats present.
Democrats also boycotted EPA Administrator designee
Pruitt&#39;s hearing.
They&#39;re doing this -- their doing their
constituents and our country a disservice by
resorting to these childish tactics.
The President&#39;s cabinet nominees will be confirmed
on the floor of the Senate, once Democrats
actually allow them to get a fair vote.
In other cabinet news, Attorney General Designee,
Senator Jeff Sessions, was voted out
of committee today.
We look forward to his full vote as the next
Attorney General.
Additionally, Secretary of State, Rex Tillerson
Designee is expected to receive a vote by the full
Senate this afternoon.
And finally, Veteran&#39;s Administration Secretary
Designee, Dr. David Shulkin will go before the
Senate Committee on Veterans Affairs at 2:30
this afternoon.
A few more things before I open it up for questions.
In terms of the schedule tomorrow, the President
will attend the National Prayer Breakfast and have
lunch with Harley Davidson&#39;s -- Harley
Davidson executives here at the White House.
The President will also meet with Senator Hatch,
Senator Wyden, Congressman
Neal and Congressman Brady.
Further guidance on all of those meetings
will be coming soon.
A few personnel announcements -- today,
the President sent the following nominations to
the Senate: Rachel L.
Brand of Iowa to be Associate Attorney
General; Steven Andrew Engle of D.C. to be
Assistant Attorney General; and, Rod J.
Rosenstein of Maryland
to be a Deputy Attorney General.
On another note, yesterday, we talked about
recent reporting concerning the President&#39;s
Executive Order protecting the nation from foreign
terrorist entry.
I want to draw your attention to some polls
that have come out on that subject.
For all the hysteria around the implementation
of this order, the American people as a whole
are very supportive of the action that the
President is taking.
A new Rasmussen report poll finds that 57
percent, which is a clear majority of likely U.S.
voters favor a temporary ban from Syria, Iraq,
Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Yemen until the
government can do a better job of keeping these
individuals out who pose a threat.
A Reuters poll found that 66 percent of Americans
believe that the United States should limit the
number of refugees into the country and the safety
of the American people and the security of American
homeland are the President&#39;s top priority
and most Americans agree with the steps that he is
taking to keep our country safe.
Further, today, the United Arab Emirates&#39; Foreign
Minister voiced his support for the President
to take our national security so seriously.
The foreign minister also added that he believes the
restrictions are not based on religion, but on the
&quot;structural problems faced by these nations.&quot; I know
that there is a question on Monday regarding Iran&#39;s
firing of a missile, an attack on a navy vessel.
I&#39;d like to introduce National Security Advisor,
General Michael Flynn to provide a quick update.
General Flynn: Thank you.
Mr. Spicer: General Flynn.
General Flynn: Good afternoon, everyone.
Recent Iranian actions involving a provocative
ballistic launch and an attack against a Saudi
naval vessel conducted by Iran supported hoothi
militants underscore what should have been clear to
the international community all along Iran&#39;s
destabilizing behavior
across the entire Middle East.
The recent ballistic launch is also
in defiance of U.N.
Security Council Resolution 2231, which
calls upon Iran not to undertake any activity
related to ballistic missiles designed to be
capable of delivering nuclear weapons, including
launches using such ballistic technology.
These are just the latest of a series of incidents
in the past six months in which hoothi forces that
Iran has trained and armed, have struck Emirati
and Saudi vessels and threatened United States
and Allied vessels transiting the Red Sea.
In these and other similar activities, Iran continues
to threaten U.S.
friends and allies in the region.
The Obama Administration failed to respond
adequately to Tehran&#39;s malign actions, including
weapons transfers, support for terrorism, and other
violations of international norms.
The Trump Administration condemns such actions by
Iran that undermine security, prosperity and
stability throughout and beyond the Middle East and
place -- which places American lives at risk.
President Trump has severely criticized the
various agreements reached between Iran and the Obama
Administration, as well as the United Nations as
being weak and ineffective.
Instead of being thankful to the United States in
these agreements, Iran is now feeling emboldened.
As of today, we are
officially putting Iran on notice.
Thank you.
Mr. Spicer: Thanks, General.
We are going to have a background briefing with
NSA staff -- NSC staff, rather, today at 4:00 here
in the briefing room.
Further details will be provided on that subject.
So, thank you, General with that.
As we start off, I mentioned yesterday, I&#39;m
pleased that we&#39;ve expanded the briefing room
at least virtually, and so with that, as I begin to
take your questions, I&#39;m pleased to offer the first
ever Skype-seat question in the White House
briefing room to Kim Kalunian from WPRI in
Rhode Island. Kim?
The Press: Thank you.
Good afternoon.
Can you hear me okay?
Mr. Spicer: We can.
The Press: Great.
Just this week, the mayor of Providence, Rhode
Island began calling our capital city a
sanctuary city.
As we know, President Trump&#39;s Executive Order
says the White House will begin publicizing a weekly
list of these municipalities and pledges
to withdraw federal grant money from them.
What I&#39;m wondering is, how soon can we expect to see
this list and how soon should cities like
Providence expect to see their federal funding cut?
Mr. Spicer: Thanks, Kim.
I think the President&#39;s goal in ending sanctuary
cities is pretty clear.
We want to, as we mentioned with these
others actions, keep America safe.
The goal is to make sure on two fronts: one, we are
doing everything we can to protect American citizens,
institutions and ending sanctuary cities is one of
the way in which we continue to do that.
Furthermore, the President&#39;s been very
clear through his Executive Order that
federal funds paid for by hard working taxpayers
should not be used to help fund sanctuary cities.
As we continue to implement this Executive
Order and fulfill the pledge that he made, we&#39;ll
have further updates on how we intend to -- how
that list will come out and when it come out, so I
look forward to following up on that as well.
With that, David Jackson.
The Press: David is not here, but I&#39;ll ask
a question.
Mr. Spicer: Go for it.
(laughter)
The Press: (inaudible) Skype.
(laughter)
The Press: The President&#39;s daily briefing has been --
remained of daily intelligence briefing.
Can you tell me how that differs at all
from the PDB?
Is the President receiving his intelligence briefing
in writing or orally and who is giving it to him?
Mr. Spicer: He did receive an intelligence briefing
today with Congressman -- or Director
Pompeii was here.
General Flynn, his National Security Advisor
-- his briefer, so he receives an intelligence
briefing and the PBD every day.
The Press: Is there any sense that we should get
out of the renaming from the PDB?
Mr. Spicer: I think that it is a more comprehensive
-- I think, again, we went through this during the
transition period, right.
There is a difference between the raw
intelligence and the analysis and I think he is
constantly updated by his National Security team and
other intelligence officials, but every
single day, he does receive the PDB.
And the -- and then I think on top of that, he&#39;s
receiving intelligence briefings from his team.
The Press: But the oral briefing does not
necessarily happen every day?
Mr. Spicer: Well, I can get back to you on that.
He does get the PDB every day and on a regular -- on
a daily basis meets
with his intelligence team, yes. Hunter?
The Press: Two quick questions on --
Mr. Spicer: We&#39;re not going to do this again.
The Press: On Black History Month.
Mr. Spicer: Yeah.
The Press: Is President Obama being invited to any
of the Black History Month celebrations?
Mr. Spicer: Not that I&#39;m aware of.
It&#39;s day one.
We just started it off.
We&#39;ll have to get back to you on further details.
I think --
The Press: A second one if I may?
Mr. Spicer: I think we have a lot -- there&#39;s a
lot of activity since I mentioned that the
President is going to do to celebrate and honor
this month, and this was just the first day of the
month of February.
The Press: Today, he made the comment about
Frederick Douglass being recognized more and more.
Do you have any idea what specifically, he was
referring to?
Mr. Spicer: Well, I think there&#39;s contribution.
I think he wants to highlight the
contributions that he has made and I think that
through a lot of the actions and statements
that he&#39;s going to make, I think the contributions of
Frederick Douglass will
become more and more. Kristin?
The Press: Thank you.
Very quickly, can you clarify what was meant by,
&quot;We&#39;re putting Iran on notice?&quot;
Mr. Spicer: Well, as I mentioned, I think General
Flynn and the NSC staff will have a
briefing at 4:00.
They can go forward on the -- I&#39;m not going to get --
I think we wanted to make very clear that we felt as
though that -- their actions were both
provocative and a violation and making sure
that they understood that we weren&#39;t going to sit by
and not act on those actions.
The Press: Are you building the case on --?
Mr. Spicer: I&#39;m just -- I&#39;m not going to go any
further than that Kristin.
No, no.
The Press: Let me ask you about -- let me just ask
you about the confirmation hearings.
Mr. Spicer: Okay.
The Press: How does the President plan to get
Chuck Schumer on board with his pick for the
Supreme Court, Neal Gorsuch, when he has
referred to him as a clown and accused him
of fake tears?
Mr. Spicer: Well, I think those are two things.
I think we&#39;re going -- you look at the support that&#39;s
already come out.
I think there&#39;s eight senators already that have
talked about the need to have a vote and
his qualifications.
And not just the Senate, but I mean, you look at
the widespread support that came out for Judge
Gorsuch last night across the spectrum.
No matter your philosophical view of the
court, I think his qualifications for the
court; his academic background make him an
unbelievably highly qualified person and so
it&#39;s not just Chuck Schumer, I think the rest
of the Senate as he goes up there.
But I think the interesting --
The Press: Chuck Schumer --
Mr. Spicer: Hold on, hold on.
The Press: (inaudible)
Mr. Spicer: Hold on.
I understand that and I think Chuck Schumer has
shown time and time again through this confirmation
process with the Cabinet that he&#39;s more interested
in politics than actually
moving the government along.
And I think that&#39;s -- that is troubling.
I would ask you that I think the question needs
to be asked to Chuck Schumer, &quot;Why are you
stalling all of these nominees?
What are you insisting on new requirements that you
didn&#39;t assume for Sotomayer Kagan?&quot;
I mean, there&#39;s a point at which they need to get
asked, why are they obstructing government at
every step of the way.
There&#39;s an element to which they need to be held
accountable as well.
They held certain standards in place for
their nominees, both for the Bench and for the
Cabinet and the question is, &quot;Are they going to
live up to the same standards that imposed on
Republicans when they had nominees in a
Democratic White House?&quot;
The Press: But does the President think that by
personally insulting Chuck
Schumer in that sort of way --
Mr. Spicer: But again, Kristin, I think the goal --
The Press: (inaudible)
Mr. Spicer: -- I think the goal --
The Press: (inaudible) members --
Mr. Spicer: -- to get --
The Press: -- when Chuck --
Mr. Spicer: -- but again, I would go back.
Chuck Schumer is not innocent in this.
There&#39;s a lot of comments that he&#39;s made and a lot
of accusations that he&#39;s thrown out there and a lot
of politics that he&#39;s played.
At some point, Chuck Schumer needs to be
held accountable for his
actions and his words. Blake.
The Press: (inaudible) built the possibility on
the Supreme Court, John, possibility of going the
route of the nuclear option.
If it gets to that point, is the White House
comfortable with that path?
Mr. Spicer: I think the President made clear his
goal today, which is number one, he believes
Judge Gorsuch is unbelievably qualified,
and that he will get nominated and not only
confirmed, but done so
with a large bipartisan vote.
As I said at the outset, Republicans looked at the
qualifications of the two justices that got through
in the Obama Administration and while
they may not have agreed with their judicial
philosophy, definitely agreed that they were
qualified on the merits to be confirmed
and they did so.
I think we would ask that we be held to the same
standard that the Democrats used when they
had nominees up.
But I think the President made very clear that the
decision is something that we would rather not have
to go down, but also, that it ultimately is up to
Senator McConnell and how
he wants to operate this thing.
John (inaudible).
The Press: Thank you, Sean.
Just one question today.
Ms. Spicer: Yeah.
The Press: Leading up to Judge Gorsuch&#39;s
announcement last night and him coming out after,
there were still rumors that Judge Hardiman was
going to be nominated and he, in fact, drove to
Washington --
Mr. Spicer: No, actually, John.
He didn&#39;t.
That was media -- that was misreporting.
My understanding is that Judge Hardiman never left
the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.
So, with all due respect, I can&#39;t be held
accountable for mis -- you know, reports that falsely
stated he was here.
He never was at the White House.
My understanding is that he had a meeting in
Eastern Pennsylvania with another judge, but it was
-- my -- and again, I&#39;m not -- I don&#39;t track where
his whereabouts, but my understanding is that he
never left the Commonwealth of
Pennsylvania yesterday, so it was, you know, we
announced when we were going to make this
announcement.
I think it was a phenomenal way to
introduce Judge Gorsuch to the American people and to
the United States Senate.
We invited Democratic leaders, Democratic
leaders -- members of the judiciary committee.
Unfortunately, none of them showed up.
But it was an opportunity for them and the American
people to see an amazing choice that the President
made for the Bench (inaudible).
The Press: Sean, my question is --
Mr. Spicer: You said one, John.
(laughter)
The Press: (inaudible) asked the question.
My question is simply this, with the support
that he received, the people called the
President, would it be safe to say that Judge
Hardiman will be on deck if there is another
vacancy soon?
Say, Justice Kennedy retiring by the end
of the term?
Mr. Spicer: Well, I think there&#39;s a lot of vacancies
that we see at the appellate level and
throughout the government.
He&#39;s an impressive, impressive jurist.
Obviously, the four that really made that final
list for the President were unbelievably
impressive.
So, I don&#39;t want to get in front of the President.
Hopefully, you know, he continues to have the
President&#39;s support and someone the President was
unbelievably impressed with.
So we&#39;ll have to see what vacancies come with down
the pike. Anita?
The Press: I know you love when we say we have two
questions.
I do have two quick questions about something
you mentioned at the top.
First, you mentioned the three folks that are being
nominated to the Department of Justice.
Mr. Spicer: Right.
The Press: Why are they being nominated now before
Senator Sessions is there?
Is it because there is a lack of people?
Was he consulted?
Or is it just because of the whole issue this week
with the acting attorney general?
Mr. Spicer: It&#39;s just a - I mean, it&#39;s the normal
process of getting those -- I&#39;ve mentioned it in a
few briefings that the deputies, the unders, and
the actings are in the pipeline.
This is -- we announced one the other day
for homeland.
We&#39;ve got the commerce is previously announced and
so this is just a continuation of the
process to fill --
The Press: (inaudible) under Sessions.
I mean, speaking with him and?
Mr. Spicer: Of course, he was -- these are people
that he&#39;s clearly aware of and supportive of
100 percent. Yeah.
The Press: And the second question was, you
mentioned tomorrow the meeting with the Harley
Davidson executives.
There&#39;s reporting that he was supposed to go to
Milwaukee tomorrow or he was supposed to.
That was canceled because of the company.
Can you talk about that?
Mr. Spicer: Yeah, I just think -- look, it was
easier for the -- for the executives to come here
considering the week and all of the activity
that&#39;s been going on.
And we figured the easiest thing to do was, again, no
decision had been made about or announced as to
what we were doing.
We looked at different options and ultimately,
the easiest thing to do in accordance with the
President&#39;s schedule was to invite them here to
Washington to talk about some of the stuff that
we&#39;ve been doing.
The Press: Are you concerned about
protesting?
Mr. Spicer: We&#39;re not concerned.
I think we&#39;re not concerned about that.
We&#39;re concerned about -- we&#39;re concerned about
American jobs, moving this economy forward, and we&#39;re
exited to welcome them here to Washington to talk
about the great work that they do and the many of
thousands of people that they employ.
With that, let me go to the -- I&#39;m going to --
we&#39;re going to be here a while, guys.
We&#39;re going to the second Skype seat.
Natalie Herbick from Fox
8 in Cleveland, Ohio. Natalie?
The Press: Secretary Spicer, thank you so much
for this rare opportunity.
I appreciate it.
I&#39;m learning the ropes now.
Mr. Spicer: Natalie, you&#39;re coming back.
The Press: I&#39;d like to quickly ask two
questions if I may?
The first one being, President Trump has been
quick to take action on several issues he&#39;s
addressed along the campaign trail.
And with that in mind, he made a stop here in
Cleveland, and he said that he would like to make
cities like ours the
economic envy of the world.
A bold statement.
So, our viewers would love to know an example -- a
specific example -- as to how he plans to do this
sooner than later.
Mr. Spicer: That&#39;s a great question, Natalie.
I think it&#39;s not just Cleveland, but it&#39;s
Detroit and so many of the other cities around the
country you&#39;ve heard the President talk about the
need to rebuild our inner cities.
We were really impressed
with Cleveland this past July.
We went there for the National Convention.
The people of Cleveland, their desire, and the
rebound that the city has taken.
And I think that when you go to whether it&#39;s a city
like Cleveland or Detroit through different tax and
regulatory measures there&#39;s a way that we can
continue to bring manufacturing back.
We can continue to bring jobs back.
And whether it&#39;s, you know, Harley Davidson or
Carrier, Lockheed, or Boeing, or the GM, Fiat,
Ford -- these companies he continues to talk with
about how they can bring jobs back, relocate.
Again, that was another one of the conversations
that he had with the pharmaceutical companies
yesterday -- how can they bring jobs back?
How can we ease regulations to do that?
So, it&#39;s about making sure that we have an
environment, Natalie, that allows more cities to
compete, to grow the manufacturing base, and to
recognize the things that we can do tax wise and
regulatory wise to allow that to flourish.
Yeah, Cecilia?
The Press: Thank you.
And Steve Bannon can be heard on recording saying,
&quot;Islam is a dark religion, not a religion of peace, a
religion of submission.&quot;
Does the President share his Chief Strategist&#39;s
apparent beliefs on Islam?
Mr. Spicer: No, I think the President&#39;s been very
clear that his number one goal is not to target any
one religion, but places and areas where we believe
that there is an issue.
That&#39;s what the executive order was all about the
other day -- making sure that areas that we don&#39;t
feel have the proper mechanisms in place to
ensure the security.
That when they travel the United States that we know
they&#39;re coming here for peaceful purposes.
The President&#39;s number one goal has always been to
focus on the safety of America, not the religion.
He understands that it&#39;s not a religious problem.
It&#39;s a radicalization problem and there&#39;s a big
difference between Islam the religion and radical
Islamic terrorists that come here to seek
to do us harm.
The Press: But nothing about this comment that
the President wants to distance himself from or
even elaborate on?
Mr. Spicer: I just think I made it clear that there&#39;s
a difference between the President&#39;s view. Yeah?
The Press: Thanks.
There have been multiple reports of people landing
Saturday in the U.S.
with valid visas who were denied entry and placed on
flights back out of the country.
So, that&#39;s in violation of at least five of these
federal judges orders that came down.
Is the White House working to ensure that those
people illegally deported can return to the U.S.?
And are these court orders causing any second
thinking about certain aspects of the order?
Mr. Spicer: Well, I think that we just -- we issued
earlier today some clarification -- an update
from the council&#39;s office that clarifies section 3C
and 3E that legal permanent residents --
LPRs -- do not -- that the waiver, we no longer
need a waiver.
Initially as the program was lifting off the idea
was that they would go through, be granted a
waiver of which everyone was issued a
waiver coming in.
In the sake of efficiency, we have interpreted the
guidance to all of these agencies to both the

Mr. Spicer: So the vote hasn&#39;t taken place.
I think we&#39;ve had some concerns in the past and I

story, and again each one of these folks who I&#39;ve
heard isn&#39;t going to make it, is going to go over

And I think that, you know, we hear it over and
over again and yet it&#39;s -- we succeed every time and
yet another roadblock is put up.
Well, this person won&#39;t succeed.
And yet, you look at each one of these people going

continue that path.
With respect to Yemen, I think it&#39;s hard to ever
say something was successful when you
lose a life.
But you&#39;ve got to understand that Chief
Owens, he went back, deployed 12 times because
he loved this country and he believed
in the mission.
And knowing that we killed an estimated 14 AQAP
members and that we gathered an unbelievable
amount of intelligence that will prevent the
potential deaths or attacks on American soil
is something that I think most service members
understand that that&#39;s why they joined the service.
And so, you never want to call something a success

was the case here, but I think that when you
recognize that an individual like this loved
this country so much and deployed over and over
again because he knew that the mission that he was
conducting was so important to our
protection, our freedom, our safety, and I know
when the President spoke to Karen, his wife, and

an unbelievably sad and emotional time for her and
her family, that he loved doing this.
And so, you know, again I don&#39;t think you ever call
anything 100 percent success, but what he did
for this nation and we got out of that mission, I
think -- I truly believe and I know the President
believes, is going to save American lives.
